Articles.Content:
Suggestion: I suggest you increase the destruction temperature of the science thermometer.

 

Reason: There doesn't seem to be a stock way to track part temperature during flight, burn, re-entry, etc.  The science thermometer would be a decent tool for this (especially now that you can pin those windows) if it didn't burn up at the temperatures of interest.  

 

Consequences: I think this would fit the stock game well.  Science devices should be fragile, but real-life temperature sensors can withstand incredible heat, and the kerbal temp. sensor feels like kind of an early-game, beat-em-up type part anyway.
Totally agree 3500-4000 hotter then anything in game.

Is anybody else interested?  I feel strongly that this should be a part of the base game, but it doesn't look like that is going to happen.  The total work involved is 1 line of code for module manager so perhaps I can make this into a mod.  Would that interest anyone?

 

Does anybody have a 30 second guide on how to publish a mod?  Seems like I need to put in on Curse, CKAN, and now I need some kind of user license?
Oh, the irony of thermometers exploding due to overheating.

While I do think thermometers should have a higher heat tolerance, they're not the only stock method of determining temperature. 

Alt+F12 menu --> Physics --> Thermal --> Display Thermal Data in Action Menus

 

Voilà! Now when you right click on a part you will get details on its skin and internal temperatures, and the various fluxes.
This is a really good, really simple idea!  Dunebugmi, you're hired!

I agree with this, such a minor thing and yet it would make a major difference since you could actually measure the temp of the nose of the aircraft as its plowing through atmo.  Who knows, we might even be able to make thermometer heat shields someday (yeah i know its cheap but it sure beats antenna abuse)...
You could use Hot Spot mod for a nice part temperature readings.
Good idea.  Actually I'd like to see a second more expensive thermometer for this to reflect the extra materials cost of such an item.  Also make it much smaller.
